content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my risk-taking nature and the long duration of the game, I would opt for a mixed strategy approach to maximize my potential earnings while minimizing the chances of consistently losing.

In this game, if both players always choose R or always choose B, the other player will systematically earn more points than me. However, by choosing a mix of R and B over the 75 rounds, I can potentially exploit the opponent's choices and increase my earnings.

One possible strategy could be to play R on the first round as it offers higher rewards if the opponent chooses B (35$ compared to 40$). If the opponent plays B, I could adjust my subsequent strategy accordingly. Conversely, if the opponent chooses R on the first round, I might consider adjusting my strategy for the remaining rounds.

Ultimately, my choice would depend on various factors such as the opponent's potential strategy, their predictability, and the number of rounds we have to play. Nevertheless, without additional information about the opponent, I would start with R on the first round (R}).
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I have learned that my opponent also chooses R when given the opportunity for a higher joint reward (45$) rather than a unilateral advantage (35$ or 0$).

Given this information, I will adapt my strategy to capitalize on the opportunity presented by the game's structure. In round two, I will choose B as my response to the opponent's R choice in the previous round. By doing so, I can earn a guaranteed 35$ while minimizing the chance of a zero payout if the opponent were to change their strategy to R again.

At the same time, choosing B also opens up the possibility of receiving an even higher reward if my opponent chooses R in this round (40$). If my opponent continues to choose R, I can adjust my subsequent choices accordingly and seek opportunities to earn more by exploiting their predictability.

In summary, for round two, I will choose B (B}).
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, I have chosen B, my opponent has also chosen B, and we both receive a payoff of 40$.

Given that my opponent and I have both shown a preference for earning a joint reward (40$) over unilateral advantages in previous rounds, I will adopt a similar strategy for round three. However, to keep the opponent guessing and maintain an element of surprise, I will slightly alter my strategy by choosing R in round three (R}).

This decision allows me to receive 35$ if my opponent chooses B, while keeping open the possibility of earning even more (45$) if my opponent decides to switch their strategy to R. If my opponent also chooses R, I can then adjust my subsequent choices based on that information and continue seeking opportunities to maximize my earnings throughout the game.

In summary, for round three, I will choose R (R}).
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this case, my initial strategy has proven successful in earning a high reward (45$) for both players in the first two rounds by choosing R twice (RR).

However, to maintain an element of unpredictability and prevent the opponent from easily anticipating my moves, I will now switch my strategy and choose B for round three (RB). This decision allows me to earn a guaranteed 35$ if my opponent chooses R, while keeping open the possibility of earning even more (40$) if my opponent decides to switch their strategy to B.

If my opponent also chooses B in round three, I can then adjust my subsequent choices based on that information and continue seeking opportunities to maximize my earnings throughout the game.

In summary, for round three, I will choose B (RB}.
